While advancing an overall program of
tax relief for homeowners Ito be featured
in the next of this series of reports), Dick
Kleindienst states that there is an immedi-
ate opportunity to begin correcting inequi-
ties in school district taxes.


He is urging Eyes" vote on Proposition
103, which will appear on the ballot in No
vember. Sponsored by the Arizona Educa-
ton Association and Parent-Teacher
groups this measure, if passed, will give the
legislature power to allocate funds to school
districts on the basis of need.


Under the present arrangement, all areas
rich and poor alike receive the same
ADA average Daily Attendance) allow
ance from the State general fund. A favor
able vote on Proposition 103 will not only
help equalize educational opportunities,
but will also relieve the heavy unfair load
on home owning taxpayers in districts that
are hard hit by increased population
and low assessed valuation.

EQUALIZATION FOR HoMEowNERs; BACKS 1903

Hats off to the Fair Play
Social Club. They have won
derful program. Their barbecue
was delicious Saturday night.


]. L. Mason prepared the food.


Houston Turner, local bowler.
was the guest of the Debonairs
Saturday night. He thanked them
for helping to sponsor him in
recent tournament.


President c. Mitchell, Senior
Missionary Society, said the
rummage sale held for the St.
Johns Baptist Church Saturday
was success sful.

visited her daughter, Miss Cry
stall Townsend. while her
husband, Rev. /. townsend at
tended the Missouri Conference
in St. Louis. he and Mrs. Town
send will return to Ogden. Utah.
They are former residents ofthe
city and have been living in Utah
for six years.

versary program in Los Angeles
Sum-, Oct. ID.

the words of our national presi-
dent who said that training can
not be beaten.

ALL AROUND
Flora Ruffin

A ten-point program to increase jobs in
Arizona; to add to the states wealth; to
broaden the tax base; to bring in new indus
tries; to develop and utilize recreational re-
sources; to strengthen Arizona's role in the
economy of the Inland Southwest; and to
do this by utilizing the human and natural
resources of Arizona in program OF action
with an attitude of progress and initiative.


PERSONAL SALESMANSHIP TO At
TRACT INDUSTRIES 81 will gladly ac-
cept responsibility as personal salesman
for Arizona to sell industrialists on the
many advantages of locating plants in Ari-
IONA. Our favorable acknowledgement eli
mate is high among these. We must also
equalize taxes, relieving the inequitable
burden on homeowners"


RECRUIT RETIRED BUSINESSMEN &
INDUSTRIALISTS - "The experienced,
successful businessmen and industrialists
who have retired to Arizona can be re-
cruited to form Council for Industrial De-
velopment These leaders will freely give
of their talents and advice to help us bring
industries and warehouses to our state"


ONE-EXTRA-DAY COMMITTEE -
active Arizona businessmen who travel to
other states can be asked to give one extra
day on their trips to call on business lead
ers with material explaining Arizona's
man for Arizona as we'll as for his own bust
ness enterprise"


STRENGTHEN ARIZONA DEVELOP
MENT BOARD - "This agency needs a
larger staff and possibly more funds to do
a stronger research, promotional and SELL
ing job for our state. 1t can cooperate with
OPERATION Payroll

The response to this dynamic program
has been enthusiastic. AS Kleindienst
points out, Each new industrial job
brought to Arizona will mean at least four
new jobs for other citizens in collateral in
dustries. In addition, many new businesses
will start up in retail trade and services to
support each plant, which will add still
more jobs to the States overall payroll"


A capsule outline of Operation Payroll"
follows Any voter interested in the eco
nomic future of present workers as we'll as
the future of youngsters who will need jobs
in the years to come, will find this proposal
worth studying:

From recent television interview :.
MIR. Kleindienst, some folks say
you are rather blunt and outspoken.
Is this so?


/. THAT depends on your personal
standards for the conduct of public
officials. If you want your officials
to be willing to stand up and be
counted - to tell you the whole
truth about what is going on - to
say the same things to different
groups in all parts of the State =.
ifyou want this kind of official, then
perhaps l am outspoken. am not
afraid to take a stand!"
From recent teIevision interview .

and coordinate the promotional efforts of
local chambers of commerce and assist pri-
vate firms that help bring industry, bust
ness, and tourists to the state"


GRADUATE STUDY & RESEARCHAT
UNIVERSITIES "Our state universities
and college offer a great potential for at
tracing industries of the space-age; indus
tries such as Motorola and General Electric
which work closely with the graduate fac
ulties and research Stats of universities in
training personnel for the specialized scien-
tific, engineering and administrative func-
tons of tomorrow"


BOOST TOURIST & RESORT TRADE
- "These industries can greatly be in
creased by stronger effort at every level,
starting with the Arizona Development
Boards accelerated program"


DEVELOP REcREATIoNAL RE-
SOURCES - 1.-THE four-season attractions
of Arizona, coupled with development of
our rivers, lakes, streams, mountains, des-
erts, and state and national parks offer
tremendous potential for increasing bust
ness in many categories of recreational
activities. The national trend of increased
leisure time and disposable income makes
recreation one of Americas fastest growing
industries No state offers greater variety
of attractions to this expanding market"


REGIONAL WAREHoUsING CEN.
TIERS - 1.-THE cities of Phoenix, Tucson,
and Yuma, among others, have not yet ap-
preached their potential as warehousing
centers for population of 20 million per-
sons within days drive of Arizona"


BRANCH ADMINISTRATIVE UNITS
-"Arizona has the business potential and
the physical facilities to offer countless ma
tional firms locations for branch admins
trative offices. Ford Motor Co., for example,
has established such an office in Phoenix
and is very happy with the decision"


INLAND SOUTHWEST FINANCIAL
CENTER - ARIZONA already has the larg-
est bank in the Rocky Mountain region. We
can easily become the financial center OF
the Inland Southwest because we already
are the business center of a vast area char
acterized by dynamic growth and economic
utility"


Richard c. Kleindienst

these dead shall not have died
in vain; and this nation, under
God, shall have a new birth of
Words To Remembe

1t is for us the living rather to
be dedicated to the unfinished
work which they who fought here
have thus far SO nobly advanced

national platform which calls for outright
repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley
law. This is the section which allows Ari-
zona and other states to have right-to-work
laws If the section is repealed our Arizona
law - which was enacted by vote of the
people - would be wiped out. SO per cent
of Arizona's employers could be blank
eted under the federal act"

Kleindienst declared that the strong sup
port his opponent is receiving from labor
unions Indicates he may have some kind
of private arrangement with them about
opposing right-to-work while he leaves peo-
pie in our state with the impression that he
is on the other side of the issue say this
is unfair. and that any man who aspres to
the office of governor should have the
courage to stand up and declare his posi-
ton !"
Private Arrangement With Labor Unions?

Following what appears to be we'll
established trend in the gubernatorial cam
paign, Richard Kleindienst has taken firm
stand on still another major Arizona issue
- rlght-to-work - and thus far is the only
candidate to do so.


"Arizona's right-to-work provision GER
tainly is an issue in this campaign" stated
Kleindienst my opponent is running on
